I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed loan 
of up to $4,950,000 to TTC Energy Joint Stock Company (TTC Energy); and (ii) a proposed partial 
credit guarantee (PCG) covering a principal amount of the dong equivalent of up to $5,400,000 
plus interest thereon for the Joint Stock Commercial Bank for Investment and Development of 
Vietnam (BIDV), both for the Commercial and Industrial Rooftop Solar Energy Project in Viet Nam. 
 
2.  The project entails the development of multiple rooftop solar photovoltaic facilities of 1 
megawatt (MW) or less on rooftops of commercial and industrial buildings in Viet Nam, targeting 
a total aggregate capacity of up to 118 MW. TTC Energy has already completed and financed 
with equity the project’s first 11.2 MW.1 The Asian Development Bank (ADB), in its capacity as 
the mandated lead arranger, has worked with TTC Energy to develop a financial and project 
structure that has crowded in other development finance institutions to provide longer-tenor 
United States (US) dollar financing, which local lenders are unable to offer. In addition, the 
proposed PCG has allowed BIDV to become comfortable with providing a local currency tranche 
with a tenor beyond what it typically offers. The project will be the first and largest independent 
power producer solar rooftop project in the country and will significantly increase Viet Nam’s 
commercial and industrial rooftop solar generating capacity by about 11 times, from an estimated 
11.3 MW as of May 2019 to 129.3 MW by project completion, which is expected in 2023.2 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Project Identification and Description 
 
3.  Electricity demand in Viet Nam has grown on average by 12% annually from 2005 to 2015 
and is projected to grow by more than 8.0% through 2030,3 posing a huge challenge to its energy 
sector and National Green Growth Strategy. 4 By 2025, peak demand in Viet Nam is expected to 
overtake Thailand in the Greater Mekong Subregion. Meeting this growing demand without 
significantly increasing the country’s contribution to global greenhouse gas (GHG) levels will 
require an alternative to the large-scale coal developments that are currently underway. 
 
4.  Strong projected electricity demand growth, declining coal reserves, and limited potential 
to develop further large-scale hydropower plants led the government in 2018 to create a pilot 
renewable energy program,5 which increased national solar production from 150 MW to nearly 5 
gigawatts by June 2019.6 In spite of the success of the pilot program,  Viet Nam faces a threat 
that demand for power will outpace supply as soon as 2021.7 Rooftop solar offers a quick and 
efficient way for Viet Nam to quickly deploy substantial amounts of additional renewable energy 
capacity. Unlike utility-scale projects, which need significant investments in grid infrastructure, 
rooftop solar systems can be widely deployed without substantial upgrades to the distribution

systems and are effective at meeting local demand, while reducing the burden on national power

5.  Compared with ground-mounted solar, rooftop solar has historically been difficult to 
implement at scale. Ground-mounted solar benefits from a 20-year feed-in tariff of $0.0935 per 
kilowatt-hour.8 Aside from guaranteed revenues from the state-owned offtaker, Vietnam Electricity 
(EVN),  ground-mounted  solar  benefits  from  the  US  dollar-indexation  of  the  tariff,  allowing 
international financiers to finance projects in US dollars, which is much cheaper than doing so in 
local currency. 
 
6.  In contrast, rooftop solar installations do not have a set power purchase agreement with 
EVN, and do not earn revenue in US dollars. This has prevented the market from expanding, as 
potential project developers have to rely on more expensive local currency financing. Potential 
commercial and industrial customers would typically not be able to use all the electricity generated 
by their rooftop solar systems because of downtime, such as on weekends or holidays. This 
unusable surplus power prevents potential customers from entering into take-or-pay contracts. 
The higher financing costs, combined with the inability to enter into take-or-pay contracts, have 
historically prevented the rooftop solar industry from being commercially viable. As such, as of 
June 2019, the total commercial and industrial solar rooftop segment in Viet Nam was less than 
20 MW, compared with the total solar capacity of more than 4,000 MW for utility-scale solar.9 
 
7.  Seeking to increase the adoption of rooftop solar, the Viet Nam regulators eliminated 
licensing requirements for the installation and operation of solar systems of less than 1 MW.10 In 
early 2019, the Ministry of Industry and Trade began allowing rooftop solar projects in Viet Nam 
to have two-way meters, which permitted owners of solar rooftop systems to sell unused power 
to the grid, independent of any existing sales agreement, and to receive a feed-in tariff.11 This has 
greatly improved the economics of rooftop solar and has mitigated a key risk barrier, which had 
hindered Viet Nam’s scaling up of grid-parity rooftop solar power. 
 
8.  Project  design.  The  project  entails  leasing  of  sub-1  MW  solar  systems  (each  a 
subproject) on the rooftops of commercial and industrial buildings in southern Viet Nam. All 
subprojects  will  adhere  to  the  standardized  financial,  technical,  environmental,  and  social 
framework agreed by TTC Energy and the lenders including ADB, the Netherlands Development 
Finance Company, the Norwegian Investment Fund for Developing Countries, and BIDV. BIDV 
will screen all potential customers against an agreed set of financial criteria. Individual subproject 
construction will only take place once BIDV has approved the potential lessee on behalf of the 
lenders. TTC Energy will use its equity to fully fund the installation of each solar system and 
lenders will only disburse once each subproject has completed construction and the lenders’ 
technical advisor has confirmed compliance with an agreed technical framework. 
 
9.  [CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] Lessees will also be free to enter into a 
power purchase agreement with EVN, which will purchase all surplus electricity generated by the 
solar rooftop system.

10.  Borrower and sponsor. Thanh Thanh Cong Investment Joint Stock Company (TTC) is a 
group of private and publicly owned legally independent companies. All of TTC’s companies and 
subsidiaries are ultimately owned or controlled by Dang Van Thanh’s family. TTC began in 1979 
as a sugar and molasses company and has grown into a leading Vietnamese conglomerate with 
more  than  10,000  employees  working  in  four  core  business  sectors:  real  estate,  energy, 
agriculture, and tourism.12 In 1991, Dang Van Thanh, the TTC chairperson, took control of a small 
rural bank, Saigon Thuong Tin Commercial Joint Stock Bank (Sacombank),13 and turned it into 
one of the largest commercial banks in Viet Nam.14 
 
11.  TTC is a renewable energy pioneer in Viet Nam. Beginning in 2003, TTC-Bien Hoa Joint 
Stock Company was among the few sugar companies in Viet Nam to begin installing sugar 
bagasse cogeneration facilities at their sugar plants. Today, TTC-Bien Hoa Join Stock Company 
has 88.6 MW of total biomass generation capacity. The TTC energy unit, Gia Lai Electricity Joint 
Stock Company (GEC), owns and operates 14 small and medium-sized hydropower plants with 
total capacity of about 100 MW. In 2017, GEC received an equity injection from Armstrong South 
East  Asia  Clean  Energy  Fund.  Armstrong  South  East  Asia  Clean  Energy  Fund  and  the 
International Finance Corporation are now the second and third largest shareholders of GEC, 
after the Dang family. GEC is listed on the Ho Chi Minh Stock Exchange. 
 
12.  Following the release of feed-in tariffs for wind and solar power, TTC identified wind and 
solar power as its most important investment priority and future growth driver. In late 2018, TTC 
(through GEC) completed and connected to the national grid the first large-scale solar projects 
under Vietnam’s renewable pilot program in Thua Thien-Hue province (35 MW) and Gia Lai 
province (69 MW). Under separate joint ventures, GEC, as the majority shareholder, worked with 
Gulf Energy (Thailand) to develop two additional solar farm projects (69 MW and 50 MW), which 
were completed in mid-2019. The TTC group is the largest and most experienced private sector 
operator of renewable energy in Viet Nam. 
 
13.  TTC Energy, the borrower, was established in 2017 as a subsidiary to spearhead TTC’s 
efforts in the solar rooftop business. TTC Energy targets commercial and industrial buildings as 
potential clients because of their large usable rooftop space and strong incentives to reduce 
electricity costs, as their cost per kilowatt-hour is in the highest grid electricity price brackets. As 
of January 2020, TTC Energy had completed nearly 50 rooftop solar installations totaling 11.2 
MW,15 and was responsible for more than 60% of the total solar rooftop capacity in Viet Nam. All 
of TTC Energy’s existing rooftop projects use Sharp panels. 
 
14.  ADB conducted integrity due diligence.16 TTC Energy, its shareholders, and its executives 
and management, as well as its significant contracting entities, do not appear to constitute a 
significant or potentially significant integrity risk as there are no unresolved or substantiated 
adverse media or relevant information related to them. Tax integrity due diligence was not 
required.

B.  Development Impacts, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
15.  Impacts. The Revised National Power Development Plan, 2011–2020 aims to prioritize 
the development of renewable energy sources for power production and increase solar power 
capacity to 850 MW by 2020, about 4,000 MW by 2025, and 12,000 MW by 2030. 17 The project 
is aligned with the following impacts: the contribution of solar energy increased, GHG emissions 
lowered, and Viet Nam’s power supply diversified. The successful implementation of the project 
will demonstrate how to implement rooftop solar at scale in Viet Nam. This project structure can 
be replicated across ADB member countries. 
 
16.  Outcome. The project will have the following outcome: supply of clean power to the 
commercial  and  industrial  sectors  increased.  It  will  generate  about  123,000  MW-hours  of 
electricity per year and reduce about 107,000 tons of carbon dioxide equivalent emissions per 
year.18 
 
17.  Outputs. The outputs of the project will be as follows: (i) total installed rooftop solar 
capacity increased to 118 MW with a marketing strategy focused on promoting TTC Energy’s 
products and services to women developed and executed; (ii) at least 150 permanent jobs 
created; (iii) gender inclusiveness of TTC Energy improved through employment targets, internal 
policies and training; and (iv) local economy supported through domestic purchases of at least $2 
million per annum.  
 
C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
18.  Consistency with ADB strategy and country strategy. The project supports private 
sector participation in infrastructure, a core pillar of ADB’s long-term strategy as affirmed by its 
Strategy 2030.19 The project is consistent with ADB’s country partnership strategy for Viet Nam, 
2016–2020 in supporting the expansion of infrastructure and environment-friendly technologies 
for clean energy generation.20 It also contributes to the objectives of Viet Nam’s Revised National 
Power Development Plan, 2011–2020.21 
 
19.  Consistency with sector strategy and relevant ADB operations. The project aligns 
with ADB’s energy policy, which encourages interventions designed to shift reliance on fossil fuel 
sources for energy to renewable forms of energy to slow down the growth of GHG emissions and 
help countries achieve energy self-sufficiency.22 The project will increase Viet Nam’s use of 
renewable energy and reduce reliance on fossil fuels such as coal, thereby mitigating GHG 
emissions. It is also aligned with Viet Nam’s commitments to the United Nations Framework 
Convention on Climate Change and will contribute to ADB’s target of providing $80.0 billion in 
climate finance by 2030.23

20.  Lessons from previous operations. This is the first large-scale rooftop project for Viet 
Nam. The project has considered experience from previous ADB ground-mounted and rooftop 
solar projects in the structuring and documentation of the transaction.24 In particular, the project 
incorporated lessons in developing the technical criteria, the customer screening criteria, and the 
environment and safeguards standardized framework. The transaction is also structured such 
that installations are fully funded by equity and ADB only disburses once construction is complete, 
thus eliminating construction risk. The project builds on results and lessons from the close 
cooperation between ADB sovereign operations to better understand the countries’ objectives 
and the regulatory framework governing rooftop solar.

III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance 
 
25.  ADB’s proposed assistance will have two components: (i) a direct loan of up to $4.95 
million and (ii) a PCG covering a principal amount of the dong equivalent of up to $5.4 million to 
BIDV plus interest thereon. [CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
B.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
26.  Catalytic impact. ADB’s support for the first nonrecourse financing of a rooftop solar 
program in Viet Nam has the potential to be paradigm shifting. Viet Nam urgently needs new 
power generation to address growing demand, and rooftop solar offers a quick solution, with little 
or no cost to EVN. Successful implementation of the project would provide a considerable 
demonstration effect to the private sector regarding the viability of rooftop solar for the commercial 
and industrial market segments. 
 
27.  Improving commercial viability and compliance. ADB’s PCG is essential for BIDV’s 
participation in the project. Lending from BIDV and Netherlands Development Finance Company 
in local currency significantly mitigates the foreign exchange risk, which is often a difficult or cost-
prohibitive barrier for most private sector projects in Viet Nam. ADB is also able to offer the longer-
tenor debt that infrastructure projects typically require, improving the commercial viability of the 
project. ADB’s participation also promotes stringent governance, and extensive environmental 
and social due diligence. 
 
28.  Mobilization  of  financing.  As  the  mandate  lead  arranger,  ADB  is  responsible  for 
structuring the debt and arranging the finance. [CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
29.  Demonstration  of  a  scalable  model  for  private  sector  financing  of  distributed 
renewable energy projects. Rooftop solar programs are typically more difficult to implement 
than ground-mounted solar. It is difficult to find the correct balance in establishing a standardized 
financial and technical framework that ensures a creditworthy portfolio of subprojects, yet does 
not inhibit the growth and competitiveness of the project sponsor. If this project is successfully 
implemented, it will be replicable and scalable not only in Viet Nam, but in other ADB member 
countries.

IV.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
 
34.  ADB  has  categorized  the  investment  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement (2009) as follows: environment (category C), involuntary resettlement (category C), 
and indigenous peoples (category C).26 
 
35.  ADB has undertaken due diligence and reviewed the potential environmental and social 
impacts of the project and the measures to avoid, minimize, mitigate, and compensate for the 
adverse impacts in the safeguard reports and plans. The environmental and social measures and 
the institutional capacity and commitment of TTC Energy to manage the project’s social and 
environmental impacts are deemed adequate. 
 
36.  The solar installations, which will be located on the rooftops of existing commercial and 
industrial buildings, are considered to have minimal potential environmental impacts. Since the 
solar panels will be located on the rooftops of buildings in commercial and industrial areas, it is 
confirmed that there will be no need to acquire land and no potential adverse impacts on 
indigenous peoples’ land. In addition, TTC Energy’s environment, health, and safety plan has 
been  reviewed  and  will  be  enhanced  to  be  consistent  with  applicable  national  laws  and 
regulations, as well as with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement requirements. Effective measures 
to avoid, minimize, and mitigate potential adverse impacts will be incorporated in the environment, 
health, and safety plan of the borrower. The borrower will monitor and report their compliance 
with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement and relevant national laws, standards, and guidelines in 
the annual environmental and social performance reports. 
 
37.  Effective gender mainstreaming. Following ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development 
(1998), TTC Energy has incorporated measures to promote gender equality and/or women’s 
empowerment in its business activities. Key features of the gender action plan include: (i) a 
marketing  strategy  focused  on  promoting  TTC  Energy’s  products  and  services  to  women 
developed and executed; (ii) an anti-sexual harassment policy developed and implemented; (iii) 
a female employee retention and promotion policy developed and implemented on recruitment, 
compensation, opportunities for growth, and promotion; (iv) an increase in female employees, 
particularly in technical or engineering capacities; and (v) a new internship or apprenticeship 
program for women in engineering. TTC Energy will submit periodic reports on the implementation 
of gender measures to ADB. 
 
38.  TTC Energy will comply with national labor laws and, pursuant to ADB’s Social Protection 
Strategy (2001), will take measures to comply with the internationally recognized core labor 
standards.27 TTC Energy will report regularly to ADB on (i) its and its contractors’ compliance with 
such laws and (ii) the measures taken. Information disclosure and consultation with affected 
people will follow ADB requirements.28 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
39.  TTC Energy was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice 
relating to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will

D.  Assurances 
 
41.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),29 
ADB will proceed with the proposed assistance upon establishing that the Government of Viet 
Nam has no objection to the proposed assistance to TTC Energy. ADB will enter into suitable 
finance documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the 
proposed assistance by the ADB Board of Directors. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
42.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan and partial credit guarantee would comply with the 
Articles of Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board 
approve 
(i)  the loan of up to $4,950,000 from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to TTC Energy

metadata.Subject:
The project entails the development of multiple rooftop solar photovoltaic facilities of 1 megawatt (MW) or less on rooftops of commercial and industrial buildings in Viet Nam, targeting a total aggregate capacity of up to 118 MW.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated January 2020 is provided for the ADB project 53147-001 in Viet Nam.
